name: Nuclear Binding Energy
latex: E_{binding} = \Delta m c^2, \quad \Delta m = Zm_p + Nm_n - m_{nucleus}
explanation: Binding energy is the energy holding nucleus together. Mass defect (Δm) is difference between sum of individual nucleon masses and actual nucleus mass. Binding energy E = Δmc². Larger binding energy per nucleon = more stable nucleus. Peak stability around iron (Fe). Nuclear reactions release energy when moving toward more stable nuclei (fusion or fission).

examples.problem: Why does nuclear fusion release energy?
examples.solution: Product nuclei have higher binding energy per nucleon
steps: Light nuclei (H, He) have low binding energy
Fusing creates heavier, more stable nuclei
Mass defect converted to energy (E = mc²)
Sun fuses H → He, releasing energy

examples.problem: Why does fission of heavy nuclei release energy?
examples.solution: Splitting heavy nuclei creates products closer to iron (peak stability)
steps: Heavy nuclei (U, Pu) are less stable
Fission products are closer to iron
Higher binding energy per nucleon in products
